The deep voice is supposedly the Taxman, he isn’t counting the rhythm, as it doesn’t match up with the song, but he is actually counting his money.

Don’t ask me what I want it for
 (Haha, Mr. Wilson)
 If you don’t want to pay some more
 (Haha, Mr. Heath)

Mr. Wilson and Mr. Heath refer to Harold Wilson and Edward Heath. Wilson was the Prime Minister of the UK at the time of recording, his first term in office lasting 1964-1970. His Labour government was responsible for the high taxes described in this song.

Edward Heath was the Leader of the Conservative Opposition, later becoming PM himself from 1970-1974 – only to be defeated again by Wilson, who was PM for a second tenure from 1974-1976.

For the purpose of this song, they serve as a personification of the British tax-collecting state.

Now my advice for those who die
 (Taxman!)
 Declare the pennies on your eyes
 (Taxman!)

Ancient Greek tradition required coins to be placed over the eyes of a dead person before burial as payment to Charon, the ferryman who conveyed souls to the underworld.



The Taxman is so ruthless, however, that you are advised to declare those pennies as taxable income, lest you suffer. Not even the dead can escape taxation!

Let me tell you how it will be
 There’s one for you, nineteen for me

Written from the perspective of the “Taxman,” this describes a 95% tax rate.  As Harrison stated:

In those days we paid nineteen shillings and sixpence out of every pound [there were twenty shillings in the pound].

According to a Bloomberg article:

The top rate for British taxpayers in the mid-1960s reached 83 percent. The wealthiest among them paid a 15 percent super-tax on top of that, pushing taxes as high as 98 percent.

According to their accountant Harold Pinsker “the first £100,000 earned was taxed at 87.5% and the second at 98%.”

This high rate of taxation led to the Beatles setting up Apple Corp. By channelling their income through Apple, they could pay the much lower rate of corporation tax – instead of paying nineteen and sixpence in the pound, they paid only sixteen shillings.

Another big British band of that time, The Rolling Stones, even left the country in 1971 to flee from a 93% income tax before releasing Exile on Main St.. The high taxes in Great Britain were also the subject of The Kinks‘ “Sunny Afternoon”.
